title: Course overview
text:
What is a Dashboard?

Dashboards provide a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives.
They consolidate and arrange information on a single screen.

Key Characteristics of Effective Dashboards

Clarity: Information should be easy to read and interpret.
Accuracy: Data must be accurate and up-to-date.
Relevance: Content should align with user goals and needs.

title: Course overview
text: Definition by Stephen Few

title: Course overview
text:
The Role of Visual Design

Minimize distractions and unnecessary elements.
Use consistent layouts and formatting.
Apply thoughtful use of color and typography.

Best Practices for Dashboard Design

Avoid clutter: Only display essential information.
Prioritize data: Highlight key metrics and KPIs.
Use visual hierarchy: Direct the viewer‚Äôs focus to the most important elements.

title: Course overview
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Overloading the user with too much data.
Using overly complex or inconsistent designs.
Neglecting the importance of user testing.

What You Shoud Do

Focus on the needs and goals of the dashboard‚Äôs end-users.
Iteratively test and refine designs to improve usability.

title: Course overview
text:
Summary

Dashboards are powerful tools for decision-making.
Effective dashboards balance clarity, relevance, and visual appeal.
Avoid common pitfalls by focusing on user needs and testing designs.

title: Welcome to The Human Side of Shipping
About
text:
Ever wondered who brings your morning coffee, your favorite sneakers, or the latest gadget to your doorstep?
Behind every package, there‚Äôs a journey at sea that is filled with hard work, sacrifice, and untold stories.
This project is more than just a data analysis but it‚Äôs a reminder that behind every order placed online, there are real people navigating the vast oceans to make it possible.
It challenges consumers to think beyond convenience and engage with the reality of global supply chains.
As we move toward a future of ever-increasing e-commerce, the question remains: how can we, as consumers, ensure that the invisible workforce of shipping is recognized, valued, and protected?

title: Shipping Survey
text:
Please take a moment to complete this quick survey and share your thoughts on shipping!

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
This dataset was collected to analyze consumer awareness, shopping behaviors, and perceptions of global shipping logistics. The data reveals how consumers view fast delivery, ethical concerns, and the labor behind shipping operations.
Dataset Overview
Total Responses: 100 (Complete survey participants)
Number of Questions: 10+
Categories Covered:
Demographics: Age, Gender, Occupation
Shopping Frequency & Delivery Priorities
Awareness of Shipping Labor
Importance of Fast Delivery
Delivery Delays & Frustration
Who Consumers Blame for Delays
Public Understanding of Global Shipping
Consumer Perceptions of Retailers, Couriers, and Logistics
Purpose of This Dataset
This dataset helps us understand how consumers interact with e-commerce and delivery services, highlighting the gap between their expectations and awareness of the logistics industry.
With this data, we can explore:
‚úÖ How frequently people shop online
‚úÖ Whether they consider the labor behind shipping
‚úÖ What factors they prioritize (fast delivery vs.¬†ethical sourcing)
‚úÖ How they react to delivery delays and who they blame (retailers, couriers, or global shipping challenges)
‚úÖ Their overall knowledge of global shipping operations
How This Data Will Be Used
üõí Consumer Awareness Gap: Exploring how many never consider the workers behind shipping.
‚ö° Fast vs.¬†Ethical Delivery: Analyzing whether people prioritize speed over ethical labor conditions.
‚è≥ Delivery Delays & Frustration: Understanding how consumer patience and frustration vary.
‚ùå Who They Blame for Delays: Examining whether consumers recognize maritime challenges or hold retailers and couriers accountable.
üåç Shipping Transparency: Identifying opportunities for educating consumers on ethical logistics and global supply chains.
Below the Dataset

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
üö¢ Consumer Awareness Gap

üìä¬†Key Data Points:

52% of respondents admitted to never considering the people behind shipping.
48% are unaware of how global shipping logistics work.

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Shifting Perspectives on Maritime Labor üåç

When informed about maritime work realities, 51% of respondents expressed ethical concerns and increased appreciation for shipping workers.
Delivery experiences shape perspectives. Consumers who had faced delays were¬†more likely to consider shipping labor issues¬†than those who had never experienced disruptions.

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Shopping Frequency üõçÔ∏è

30% shop online ‚ÄúAlways‚Äù, 23% shop ‚ÄúOccasionally‚Äù¬†‚Üí Online shopping is a¬†major habit.

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Fast Delivery vs Ethical Awareness ‚ö°

Consumer Priorities Differ:

39% of respondents consider fast delivery highly important.
Only 16% rank fast delivery as ‚ÄúNot Important‚Äù.
Consumers who learned about maritime labor were 2x more likely to accept slower, ethical shipping options.

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Delivery Delays & Consumer Frustration ‚è≥

53% of respondents have experienced delivery delays.
Among those who faced delays, 60% blamed retailers or courier companies.
Only a small percentage recognized maritime labor shortages as a contributing factor. :::

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Who Do Consumers Blame? ‚ùå

üè¢ 45% blame retailers.
üöö 38% blame courier companies.
üåä Only 17% recognize global shipping delays as a factor.
A¬†majority of consumers focus on the last-mile delivery¬†rather than considering the¬†global shipping process that brings goods to their region.

title: Final Project Presentation
section: The Public‚Äôs Understanding of Global Shipping üåê
text:
The Public‚Äôs Understanding of Global Shipping üåê

51% are unaware of global shipping logistics.
Only 49% say they ‚Äúfully understand‚Äù how supply chains work.
Consumers who reported awareness of shipping labor were 3x more likely to express concern for worker conditions.
A¬†lack of transparency in supply chains leads to uninformed consumer opinions.¬†More education could¬†change behaviors and increase support for ethical logistics. :::

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
üåç The Need for Transparency

E-commerce is growing rapidly, but only¬†51% of respondents have considered how shipping workers impact their deliveries.
Consumers who learned about maritime labor were more likely to demand fair working conditions. :::

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Encouraging Ethical Consumer Behavior üõí



Consumers who acknowledged the human side of shipping were 40% more likely to support fair labor policies.
A majority of informed shoppers expressed willingness to wait longer for deliveries if it meant better conditions for workers.Opportunities for Industry Collaboration ü§ù

title: Final Project Presentation
text:
Shipping and Delivery Perceptions üì¶

üöÄ 16% prioritize fast delivery.
‚è≥ and 16% are willing to wait longer.

title: Final Project Presentation
section: Final Thoughts: A Call to Action üöÄ
text:
Final Thoughts: A Call to Action üöÄ

Consumers with greater shipping awareness were more likely to support worker rights and ethical policies.
Transparency leads to more ethical purchasing decisions and labor improvements.
Increasing consumer knowledge about the shipping industry can drive ethical trade and better labor conditions.
